results.title: City water supply
results.brief_description: Illustrates the relation between rainfall and life. The sources of a city’s water supply - wells, rivers, lakes and watersheds - are also illustrated and the film goes on to study both the varied methods which are employed to distribute water throughout a city, and the methods used to prevent the spread of disease and epidemics through water-borne bacteria.

results.title: City limits
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Forthright, critical analysis of the problems of North American cities by Jane Jacobs, authority and author of books and articles on the subject. A former New Yorker, she chose to live in Toronto because “it is a city that still has options…it hasn’t made so many mistakes that it’s bound to go downhill.” Her remarks, and what this film shows, will interest all civic and community groups - in fact, all urban dwellers. Photography by Jacques Fogel, Albert Kish, Cameron Gaul, Raymond Dumas.

results.title: A Chord for voices
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Malcolm Otton, Film Australia and OTC Australia
results.brief_description: In July 1976 a new undersea communications link was completed between Papua New Guinea, Australia and the rest of the world. Complicated cable laying techniques are shown, and in the background is the exotic and beautiful Papua New Guinea scenery. By plugging in to the international community, the indigenous people will feel greater pressure to surrender their traditions and customs, and to develop towards a more cosmopolitan way of life. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Choice is yours
results.creator_credit: Fred S Niemann and National Woman's Christian Temperance Union
results.brief_description: Features Dr Andrew C. Ivy, Head of the University of Illinois Professional Schools in Chicago, and a young boy and girl questioning a chemistry teacher about alcohol. Through animation, the film shows physical effects of alcohol.

results.title: China!
results.creator_credit: Felix Greene and Dateline Film Productions
results.brief_description: Felix Greene spent several months and travelled over 15,000 miles throughout China to make this visual report on the day-to-day life of the Chinese people. Covers agriculture and industry in various parts of the country and discusses the political situation. Also features aspects of Chinese culture and social customs. Contains b&w archival footage. Music recorded in China by Felix Greene with the Peking Symphony Orchestra conducted by Li Teh-Lun.

results.title: Children who draw pictures (TEFC)
results.brief_description: With colour sequences. A study of artistic activities of first grade children in a Tokyo primary school. Through the year they experiment with pencil, crayon, finger painting, oil and clay, showing development of individual observation. Shows how school and home experiences influence choice and treatment of subjects, and how feelings are communicated in creative effort.

results.title: Children of Japan
results.brief_description: A study of the daily life of a middle-class Japanese family immediately before World War II. The contrast between the influence of Western technology and the traditional customs and habits of the Japanese people is reflected in their environment.

results.title: Who killed the sale?
results.creator_credit: Michael Tuchner, Anthony Pelissier, Ian Latimer and Rank Organisation Short Films Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Customer and You”.
An amusing film in Cleese style of a case study which shows that employees in all parts of a company can affect a company’s ability to get and to keep business. With Bud Tingwell.
